Methods

Angela Yu

Methods.Rmd

Definition of Inverse Set and Introduction of the Estimation Method

The identification of domain sets whose outcomes belong to predefined subsets can address fundamental risk assessment challenges in climatology and medicine. A motivating example involves estimating geographical regions where average difference between summer and winter temperatures exceed a certain benchmark, which help policymakers focus on specific areas that are at higher risk for effects of climate change.

Mathematically, the target region correspond to the inverse image of U‚äÇ‚ÑùU \subset \mathbb{R} under an unknown function Œº:ùíÆ‚Üí‚Ñù\mu: \mathcal{S} \to \mathbb{R}, can be defined as Œº‚àí1(U)={s‚ààS:Œº(s)‚ààU} \mu^{-1}(U) = \{s \in S: \mu(s) \in U\} , with UU a pre-specified subset of a real line ‚Ñù\mathbb{R} (e.g., [c,‚àû)[c, \infty)).

A point estimator for the inverse set can be constructed as ŒºÃÇn‚àí1(U)\hat{\mu}_n^{-1}(U), where ŒºÃÇn\hat{\mu}_n is an empirical estimator of Œº\mu based on nn observations. To quantify the spatial uncertainty of this estimation, Sommerfeld et al.¬†(2018) introduced Coverage Probability Excursion (CoPE) sets, defined as: CSin(U)‚äÜŒº‚àí1(U)‚äÜCSout(U) \text{CS}_{\text{in}}(U) \subseteq \mu^{-1}(U) \subseteq \text{CS}_{\text{out}}(U) which satisfy: ‚Ñô(CSin(U)‚äÜŒº‚àí1(U)‚äÜCSout(U))‚â•1‚àíŒ± \mathbb{P}\left(\text{CS}_{\text{in}}(U) \subseteq \mu^{-1}(U) \subseteq \text{CS}_{\text{out}}(U)\right) \geq 1 - \alpha for a pre-specified confidence level 1‚àíŒ±1-\alpha (e.g., Œ±=0.05\alpha = 0.05).

Existing approaches require restrictive assumptions, including domain density of SS in RR, continuity of ŒºÃÇn\hat{\mu}_n and Œº\mu near thresholds, and large-sample guarantees, which limit the applicability. Besides, the estimation and coverage depend on setting a fixed threshold level, which is difficult to determine.

Ren et al.¬†(2023) proposed a framework that generalizes the estimation of such inverse sets to dense and non-dense domains with protection against inflated Type I error, and constructs multiple upper, lower or interval confidence region of Œº‚àí1(U)\mu^{-1}(U) over arbitrary chosen thresholds. The coverage probability is achieved non-asymptotically and simultaneously through inverting simultaneous confidence intervals. For instance, suppose we are interested in inverse set Œº‚àí1([c,‚àû))\mu^{-1}([c,\infty)) for a single value cc, the inverse confidence region are constructed by inverting simultaneous confidence intervals (SCIs). Given SCI bounds BÃÇl(ùê¨)\hat{B}_{l}(\boldsymbol{s}) and BÃÇu(ùê¨)\hat{B}_{u}(\boldsymbol{s}) satisfying:

‚Ñô(‚àÄùê¨‚ààùíÆ:BÃÇl(ùê¨)‚â§Œº(ùê¨)‚â§BÃÇu(ùê¨))=1‚àíŒ± \mathbb{P}\left(\forall\boldsymbol{s}\in\mathcal{S}: \hat{B}_{l}(\boldsymbol{s}) \leq \mu(\boldsymbol{s}) \leq \hat{B}_{u}(\boldsymbol{s})\right) = 1-\alpha

The inner and outer CSs for the inverse upper excursion set Œº‚àí1[c,‚àû)\mu^{-1}[c, \infty) are defined as:
CSin[c,‚àû):=BÃÇ‚Ñì‚àí1[c,‚àû) \text{CS}_{\text{in}}[c, \infty) := \hat{B}_\ell^{-1}[c, \infty)

CSout[c,‚àû):=BÃÇu‚àí1[c,‚àû) \text{CS}_{\text{out}}[c,\infty) := \hat{B}_u^{-1}[c, \infty)

The outer and inner confidence region for the inverse lower excursion set Œº‚àí1(‚àí‚àû,c]\mu^{-1}\left(-\infty, c\right] are defined as:

CSin(‚àí‚àû,c]:=BÃÇu‚àí1(‚àí‚àû,c]=(BÃÇu‚àí1[c,+‚àû))‚àÅ \text{CS}_{\text{in}}\left(-\infty, c\right] := \hat{B}_u^{-1}\left(-\infty, c\right] = \left( \hat{B}_u^{-1}\left[c, +\infty\right) \right)^{\complement} CSout(‚àí‚àû,c]:=BÃÇ‚Ñì‚àí1(‚àí‚àû,c]=(BÃÇ‚Ñì‚àí1[c,+‚àû))‚àÅ \text{CS}_{\text{out}}\left(-\infty, c\right] := \hat{B}_\ell^{-1}\left(-\infty, c\right] = \left( \hat{B}_\ell^{-1}\left[c, +\infty\right) \right)^{\complement}

The inner and outer CSs for the inverse interval set Œº‚àí1[a,b]\mu^{-1}[a, b] are defined as:

CSin[a,b]:=BÃÇ‚Ñì‚àí1[a,‚àû)‚à©BÃÇu‚àí1(‚àí‚àû,b] \text{CS}_{\text{in}}[a, b] := \hat{B}_\ell^{-1}[a, \infty) \cap \hat{B}_u^{-1}(-\infty, b]

CSout[a,b]:=BÃÇu‚àí1[a,‚àû)‚à©BÃÇ‚Ñì‚àí1(‚àí‚àû,b] \text{CS}_{\text{out}}[a, b] := \hat{B}_u^{-1}[a, \infty) \cap \hat{B}_\ell^{-1}(-\infty, b]

Linear Function-on-Scalar Regression (FoSR)

A simple example for function-on-scalar regression model is

Yi(t)=Œ≤0(t)+Œ≤1(t)Xi1+bi(t)+œµi(t), Y_i(t) = \beta_0(t) + \beta_1(t) X_{i1} + b_i(t) + \epsilon_i(t),

where:

  • Yi(t)Y_i(t) is a functional outcome
  • Xi1X_{i1} is a scalar covariate
  • Each Œ≤j(t)\beta_j(t) is a coefficient function
  • bi(t)b_i(t) is a subject-specific functional random effect. This captures correlation within subjects over time that is not captured by the mean. This term is not always included in FoSR models, but it‚Äôs generally a good idea because it gives better inference
  • œµi(t)\epsilon_i(t) are normally distributed iid errors

Here, the same bases are used for Œ≤1(t)\beta_1(t) and Œ≤2(t)\beta_2(t).

Accounting for Error Correlation

The fitted GAM model above didn‚Äôt take the correlation of residuals into account. Here, we combined random effects and FPCA into the GAM model to resolve this.

Modeling residuals with FPCA and gam

First, fit the mean model:

Yi(t)=Œ≤0(t)+Œ≤1(t)Xi1+ei(t), Y_i(t) = \beta_0(t) + \beta_1(t) X_{i1} + e_i(t),

Estimate the FPCA for GAMM FPCA model

After obtaining residuals from the mean model, FPCA models the residuals using equation ei(s)=bi(s)+œµi(s)e_i(s) = b_i(s) + \epsilon_i(s), where bi(s)b_i(s) follows a mean zero Gaussian Process (GP) with covariance function Œ£\Sigma, and œµi(s)\epsilon_i(s) are independent N(0,œÉe2)N(0, \sigma_e^2) random errors.

Assuming that œïk(‚ãÖ)\phi_k(\cdot) are the eigenfunctions of the covariance operator KXK_X of bi(‚ãÖ)b_i(\cdot), one can express:

bi(t)=‚àëk=1‚àûŒæikœïk(t) b_i(t) = \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \xi_{ik} \phi_k(t)

The GAMM-FPCA model will be :

Yi(t)=Œ≤0(t)+Œ≤1(t)Xi1+‚àëk=1KŒæikœïk(t)+œµi(t), Y_i(t) = \beta_0(t) + \beta_1(t) X_{i1} + \sum_{k=1}^{K} \xi_{ik} \phi_k(t) + \epsilon_i(t),

Construction of Simultaneous Confidence Bands for Functional Regression Model

Correlation and Multiplicity Adjusted (CMA) Confidence Bands Based on Parameter Simulations

  1. Simulate model parameters ùõÉ1,‚Ä¶,ùõÉB‚àºi.i.d.ùí©(ùõÉÃÇ,VÃÇùõÉ)\boldsymbol{\beta}_1, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\beta}_B \overset{\text{i.i.d.}}{\sim} \mathcal{N}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, \hat{V}_{\boldsymbol{\beta}}) , where (ùõÉÃÇ,VÃÇùõÉ)(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, \hat{V}_{\boldsymbol{\beta}}) are estimated via a fitted FoSR model.

  2. For each b=1,‚Ä¶,Bb = 1, \ldots, B, compute ùêób=ùêÅ(Œ≤b‚àíŒ≤ÃÇ)ùêÉf \mathbf{X}_b = \frac{\mathbf{B}({\beta}_b - \hat{{\beta}})}{\mathbf{D}_f} , where the division is element-wise and ùêÅ\mathbf{B} maps parameters to functional effects.

  3. Let db=max(|ùêób|),b=1,‚Ä¶,B d_b = \max(|\mathbf{X}_b|), \quad b = 1, \ldots, B , where the absolute value is taken element-wise.

  4. Estimate q(Cf,1‚àíŒ±)q(C_f, 1 - \alpha) as the 100‚ãÖ(1‚àíŒ±)100 \cdot (1 - \alpha) percentile of {d1,‚Ä¶,dB}\{d_1, \ldots, d_B\}.

Multiplier-t Bootstrap Procedure for Constructing Confidence Bands

  1. Compute residuals R1N,‚Ä¶,RNNR_1^N, \ldots, R_N^N, where RnN=NN‚àí1(Yn‚àíŒºÃÇN)R_n^N = \sqrt{\frac{N}{N - 1}} \left( Y_n - \hat{\mu}_N \right), and multipliers g1,‚Ä¶,gN‚àºi.i.d.gg_1, \ldots, g_N \overset{\text{i.i.d.}}{\sim} g with ùîº[g]=0\mathbb{E}[g] = 0 and var[g]=1\mathrm{var}[g] = 1.

  2. Estimate œµÃÇN*(s)\hat{\epsilon}_N^*(s) from g1Y1(s),‚Ä¶,gNYN(s)g_1 Y_1(s), \ldots, g_N Y_N(s).

  3. Compute T*(s)=1N‚àën=1NgnRnN(s)œµÃÇN*(s) T^*(s) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \sum_{n=1}^N g_n \frac{R_n^N(s)}{\hat{\epsilon}_N^*(s)}

  4. Repeat steps 1 to 3 many times. Take the (1‚àíŒ±)‚ãÖ100%(1 - \alpha) \cdot 100\% quantile of ‚Ñí*\mathcal{L}^* to estimate qŒ±,Nq_{\alpha, N}.

For details of the algorithm, please refer to Telschow et al.¬†(2019)

ŒºÃÇN\hat{\mu}_N will be estimated though using the fitted mean value from a functional regression model (e.g., using mgcv::bam).

In the multiplier bootstrap procedure, SCoRES supports three types of multiplier distributions, which is specified by weights:

  • "rademacher": gi‚àà{‚àí1,+1}g_i \in \{-1, +1\} with equal probability
  • "gaussian": gi‚àºùí©(0,1)g_i \sim \mathcal{N}(0, 1)
  • "mammen": A two-point distribution with mean zero and variance one (see Mammen, 1993)

Default is rademacher.

Two options are available for estimating the standard error œµÃÇN*(sj)\hat{\epsilon}_N^*(s_j), which is specified by method_SD:

  • ‚Äúregular‚Äù (empirical standard error based on residuals): œµÃÇN*(sj)=1n‚àëi=1n(Yi(sj)‚àíŒ≤ÃÇ(sj))2/(n‚àí1) \hat{\epsilon}_N^*(s_j) = \sqrt{ \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n \left( {Y}_i(s_j) - \hat{\beta}(s_j) \right)^2 / (n-1) } .

  • ‚Äút‚Äù (bootstrap second moment-based estimator): œµÃÇN*(sj)=NN‚àí1|ùîºb[Yb(sj)2]‚àí(ùîºb[Yb(sj)])2| \hat{\epsilon}_N^*(s_j) = \sqrt{ \frac{N}{N-1} \left| \mathbb{E}_b\left[ {Y}^{b}(s_j)^2 \right] - \left( \mathbb{E}_b\left[ {Y}^{b}(s_j) \right] \right)^2 \right| } , where expectations are taken over bootstrap replicates and Yb(sj){Y}^{b}(s_j) is the perturbed sample in bootstrap iteration bb. The absolute value ensures numerical stability when subtracting large, nearly equal quantities.

Default is t.
